awd_titl_txt: 2023 National Science Foundation (NSF) Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Principal Investigator (PI) Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support the planning, organization, participation, and evaluation of the 2023 National Science Foundation (NSF) Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Principal Investigator (PI) Workshop. The three-day workshop has four main goals: (1) provide opportunities for new and existing NSF CISE REU PIs and Co-PIs to share experiences directing undergraduate research programs and offer suggestions for improving all sites, (2) discuss best practices and challenges associated with the administration of an undergraduate research program, (3) provide networking and community-building opportunities for REU PIs, recognizing individual and group dedication to the importance of undergraduate research beyond home institutions, and (4) discuss the transfer of lessons learned from virtual to in-person REUs. The meeting will prepare attendees to host more impactful, inclusive, and research-generating REU sites. Resources will be shared in a publicly available website and summarized in a report and shared with all participants and the NSF community, as well as via the workshop website and Slack REU Site PIs workspace.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
A total of 101 PIs representing new and existing NSF CISE REU Sites convened in Austin, Texas from April 19-21, 2023 for the biannual NSF-sponsored CISE REU PI Workshop. This was the first in-person REU PI meeting since 2018 due to COVID-19 pandemic travel restrictions. The goals of the REU PI Workshop were to: (1) share experiences directing undergraduate research programs and offer suggestions for improving all sites; (2) discuss best practices and challenges associated with the administration of an undergraduate research program; (3) provide networking and community-building opportunities for REU PIs, recognizing individual and group dedication to the importance of undergraduate research beyond home institutions; and (4) discuss the transfer of lessons learned from virtual to in-person REUs. 

The three-day workshop featured activities to build community and exchange effective practices for engaging undergraduate students in cutting-edge research and meaningful research experiences at REU sites. REU sites aim to increase the number of professionals in computing and related disciplines that drive innovation and sustain global economic competitiveness. PIs learned about active REU sites and attended breakout sessions focused on pre-planning for REUs, REU student success onsite, and REU site innovation and sustainability. Additionally, PIs met with NSF program officers.

The agenda also included panels with REU alumni, guest speakers from NSF Education and Training Application (ETAP) and Mathematica, and PIs who shared information about transferring lessons learned from virtual to in-person REU sites; evaluation, reporting, tracking, and dissemination of longitudinal REU outcomes; writing a highly competitive renewal and new NSF funding opportunities; and broadening participation in computing. A best practices working session and tour of the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) at The University of Texas at Austin - the host institution - provided additional networking and information-sharing opportunities. 

The evaluation report and resources from the workshop were shared with all participants and the NSF community and can be found on the workshop website (https://tacc.utexas.edu/events/2023/reu-principal-investigators-work/). 

 


Last Modified: 04/01/2024
Modified by: Rosalia Gomez
